Award.AwardTitle: Effects of Native Language and Linguistic Exposure on Non-Native Listeners' Use of Prosodic Cues in Speech Segmentation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Speech is a continuous flow of sounds where no single device explicitly marks word boundaries. A crucial challenge for language learners is that the cues that signal word boundaries differ across languages; thus, a speaker's experience with her native language may be misleading when attempting to segment a second language into words. Specifying how adult language learners recognize words in continuous speech is very important, first because it can help resolve key theoretical debates about how language learning and language comprehension take place in adults. More precisely, it can shed light on whether (and if so, the extent to which) the adult brain is sufficiently plastic to develop sensitivity to new segmentation cues and the factors that modulate whether or not this learning is possible. This research can therefore have important implications for cognitive and linguistic sciences. Furthermore, speech segmentation is essential to successful communication among multilingual speakers. As our society is becoming increasingly multilingual, languages have become intrinsic components of K-12 and college curricula, and computational linguists and computer scientists have striven to develop technologies that could afford efficient communication among multilingual speakers. Investigating the factors that influence how adult language learners segment a second language into words can thus have important implications for the teaching of languages and for the development of communication technologies (e.g., automatic speech recognition).

This research focuses on the influence of the native language and of recent linguistic exposure on adult language learners' use of prosodic cues, specifically pitch, in speech segmentation. Its primary aim is to determine how the similarities and differences between the native language and second language affect adult language learners' ability to use prosodic cues in speech segmentation. Two hypotheses are tested: (i) the Prosodic Assimilation Hypothesis: Second-language prosodic systems that are similar to, yet different from, native-language prosodic systems are assimilated and thus more difficult to learn in speech segmentation than second-language prosodic systems that are very different from native-language prosodic systems; and (ii) the Cue-Weighting Transfer Hypothesis: The functional load of segmentation cues in the native language is carried over to the second language. A secondary aim of this research is to assess the effect of recent linguistic exposure on speech segmentation. A third hypothesis is tested: (iii) Probabilistic Speech Segmentation Hypothesis: The speech processing system uses a single set of speech segmentation strategies that reflect the probabilities of cues to word boundaries across the native language and second language. To test these hypotheses, this research focuses on native French, Korean, English, and Dutch listeners with or without knowledge of French or Korean as second languages. Listeners will complete visual-world eye-tracking and artificial-language segmentation experiments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

This project investigated the effects of native language (L1) and linguistic exposure on second-language (L2) learners’ use of prosodic cues (specifically, pitch) in speech segmentation. Three hypotheses were tested: (i) Prosodic-Learning Interference Hypothesis:L2 prosodic systems that are similar to, yet different from, L1 prosodic systems are more difficult to learn and use in speech segmentation than L2 prosodic systems that are very different from L1 prosodic systems, because non-native listeners assimilate the L1 and L2 prosodic systems, which in turn leads them not to restructure their cue-to-word-boundary mappings in the L2; (ii) Cue-Weighting Transfer Hypothesis: Non-native listeners rely on similar cue weightings in the L1 and the L2, such that the functional weight of prosodic cues in the L1 is carried over to the L2; and (iii) Probabilistic Speech Segmentation Hypothesis: The speech processing system uses a single set of speech segmentation strategies that reflect the probabilities of prosodic cues to word boundaries across the L1 and the L2.  

These hypotheses were tested by investigating French, English, Dutch, and Korean listeners’ segmentation of French; French, English, Dutch, and Korean listeners’ segmentation of artificial languages; and French, English, and Korean listeners’ segmentation of Korean. French andKoreanhave similar prosodic systems but differ in the alignment of pitch cues to word boundaries, with a high tone signaling word-final boundaries in both languages but with a low tone signaling word-initial boundaries only in Korean (in French, the high tone is aligned later in the word-final syllable and the following low tone is thus not aligned with word-initial boundaries). Englishand Dutchhave similar prosodic systems, with a high tone signaling word-initial boundaries (due to the common occurrence of word-initial stress) in words that receive a default sentence-level pitch accent; however, these languages differ in that pitch cues have a weaker functional weight (i.e., for signaling lexical prominence) in English compared to Dutch. The results of visual-world eye-tracking and artificial-language speech segmentation experiments provided partial support for all hypotheses tested:

(i) Prosodic-Learning Interference Hypothesis: Unlike English listeners, Korean listeners were unable to use pitch cues to word-final boundaries in French. These results were attributed to Korean listeners’ assimilation of the L2 (French) prosodic system to their L1 (Korean) system, preventing them from learning the subtle differences between the two systems and resulting in the inability to use pitch cues in French due to the later alignment of the high-low tone sequence in French compared to Korean. This pattern of results was not true of French listeners’ segmentation of Korean, however, with French listeners using the phrase-initial low tone to locate word-initial boundaries in Korean. The Prosodic-Learning Interference Hypothesis was thus refined, applying only to those cases where the L1-L2 prosodic systems are similar but where prosodic cues are closely aligned with word boundaries only in the L1. The importance of the phrase-initial low tone to segment Korean was also confirmed in native Korean listeners’ segmentation of artificial languages.

(ii) Cue-Weighting Transfer Hypothesis: Dutch listeners made greater use of pitch cues to word-final boundaries in French than English listeners, providing support for the Cue-Weighting Hypothesis. However, Dutch listeners did not make greater use of pitch cues to word-final boundaries than English listeners in the segmentation of a French-like artificial language. This lack of L1 effect was attributed to the less sensitive and more variable nature of performance in the artificial-language segmentation paradigm.

(iii) Probabilistic Speech Segmentation Hypothesis: In artificial languages, English L2 learners of French made greater use of pitch cues to word-final boundaries than monolingual English listeners; French L2 learners of English made lesser use of pitch cues to word-final boundaries than monolingual French listeners; and Dutch L2 learners of French made greater use of pitch cues to word-final boundaries than Dutch listeners with limited French knowledge. These results provide supporting evidence for the Probabilistic Speech Segmentation Hypothesis.

Broader Impacts

This proposal afforded the opportunity for direct translation from research into education: 

(i) Graduate mentorship: Graduate research assistants were trained to create speech stimuli, design experiments, collect and analyze data, and disseminate the research in conferences and in the writing of publication manuscripts; a broader pool of graduate students were trained to conduct eye-tracking research in a graduate seminar.

(ii) Involvement of under-represented undergraduate students in research: Undergraduate research assistants were recruited from several venues, including the University of Kansas McNair Scholars Program, which supports students from underrepresented minority groups and first-generation college students; the undergraduate research assistants helped recruit participants and collect data.

(iii) Outreach activities: The PI gave several presentations in two local high schools (>200 students) that introduced students to L2-acquisition research and disseminated some of the present findings, all the while encouraging students to pursue higher-level education. High-school students from an English-learning class, most of whom were from underrepresented minority groups, visited the PI’s lab.
